# News comment title:
Why Big Rigs Need Higher Fuel Standards

# Oldest comment (from the thread):
This sounds more like an argument for higher fuel standards, not lower.

You describe the market failure in great detail.  


# Most liked comment (from the thread):
That's a pretty unfair assessment of McArdle.  She said (summarizing) "MPG improvements at the low end offer bigger money savings than MPG at the high end.  Given that, and the fact that trucking companies' profitability is largely governed by fuel costs, why haven't they been voluntarily seeking out rigs with higher MPG?"

I think the criticism of her assessment following that question, is that she didn't delve deeply enough into the reality, which Kevin and his correspondent have done here.  I think they make a persuasive case, and I'm glad they did so, because I was finding it hard to disagree with McArdle, but now I see the flaw.  

Thanks for the quality post as usual Kevin.

>>> COMMENT UNDER ANALYSIS<<<

# News comment title:
The Nitty Gritty of the Jobs Plan

# Oldest comment (from the thread):
I think the GOP cares, they just don't like how the president "paid for" the proposed spending...

Which is, he didn't. He threw the ball to Congress, and said "you make the cuts, but pass my spending"

# Most liked comment (from the thread):
Your response is typical of a "progressive" - an inability to dispute FACT - censoring is the only alternative to protect your authoritarianism.

Oh, let me guess - your favorite professor was Krugman...  It should be child's play for you to dispute FACT.  Then again - maybe you're intelligent enough to understand the FACTS - but they don't mesh with your desire to push politics over all else.

>>> COMMENT UNDER ANALYSIS<<<


"And a week from Monday, I’ll be releasing a more ambitious deficit plan
 -- a plan that will not only cover the cost of this jobs bill, but 
stabilize our debt in the long run."

Be patient, and you will have something to actually criticize.

>>> END COMMENT <<<

# News comment title:
Who Will Tend the Machines That Tend the Machines?

# Oldest comment (from the thread):
Try fork trucks. Controlled environment, repetitive paths, traffic interaction is with- other automatic fork trucks. 

Sooner than you think indeed. 

# Most liked comment (from the thread):
While I understand your point, and wish that your optimism had any real-world significance, it is so true as to be tiresome that there is a small minority of extremely weathy elites whose impetus seems to be making damn well sure that those of us who are NOT part of that elite (you know, 99% of the world's population) have no choice but to take whatever exhausting, mind-numbing, soul-destroying employment comes along that, hopefully, will just barely keep ourselves and our families clothed and sheltered, and maybe, if we're lucky and one of the elites favors us with his his generosity, there might be enough left over for one of our children to get an education and find work that is slightly less exhausting, mind-numbing, and soul-destroying. But I'm not, you know, "forced to work".

>>> COMMENT UNDER ANALYSIS<<<


Nah, if we have robot-driven ctrucks, I'll bet the trucking companies will have road scanners to create maps of potholes and other pertinent data (slopes, etc) to optimize mileage and avoid maintenance. 

>>> END COMMENT <<<

# News comment title:
The Power of Flat Out Lies

# Oldest comment (from the thread):
Economist/YouGov just posted a poll putting the Pres. Job Approval at 36%.  You guys are really getting desperate for an explanation which doesn't involve the "President is failing."

# Most liked comment (from the thread):
Conservatives boo a soldier serving in Iraq and cheer letting someone with no health insurance die, and then turn around and charge progressives with supporting death panels and not supporting the troops. It's pretty dam obvious conservatives typically make up their mind first, and then make up all sorts of shit on the fly to justify it.

>>> COMMENT UNDER ANALYSIS<<<


There are two new taxes in ACA: (1) an excise tax on insurers and (2) a tax on "Cadillac" health care plans.  Those are generally going to be used to fund subsidies for low-income folks so they can pay for their health insurance.  Their health insurance will be bought from the same health insurers in operation now.  That's why it's not a substantial difference.  The health care market will change marginally-- because their are millions of new customers and their are new requirements for plans (e.g., can't exclude due to pre-existing conditions, etc.).  

I am confident that the health care industry will not change substantially beyond what is happening now, but I could be wrong.  Before ACA health care premiums have skyrocketed for years, way above the rate of inflation.  All this talk about the government ruining the laissez-faire paradise known as the health care industry and "costing wives and children their lives" are worthless campfire ghost stories based on an emotional belief that government is inherently bad.  

There simply is not a mechanism in the law for a "dirtbag middle manager [that] makes a decision that costs your wife or child their life."  But there is in the insurance industry without ACA.

>>> END COMMENT <<<

# News comment title:
Team Obama Says GOP Deliberately Tanking the Economy

# Oldest comment (from the thread):
In other news, sun rises in East, rain falls from sky, Mitch McConnell lies.

# Most liked comment (from the thread):
Obama's choice here is fairly stark. He's not going to win next year if the economy sucks and the public perceives him as ineffectual. He really doesn't have any options left except making the election a referendum on the Republican Party. Fortunately, the Republicans are even more unpopular than Obama so he has some room here to run. 

Obama needs to do this himself and he needs to do it ASAP. He's wasted almost three years on a political strategy (post-partisan  conciliation) that has made him look weak. Republicans, thuggish as they are, haven't really paid a price for their nihilism. For Obama, this is both good politics and good civics. If a major political party doesn't suffer for trying to sabotage the nation, America is not going to survive much longer. Obama's crisis is, for better or worse, a national crisis.

>>> COMMENT UNDER ANALYSIS<<<


No, I think he's right to a certain degree, although I would use a lot less colorful language.  He clearly thinks this is some kind of indictment of the Obama admin, which I don't.  It seems to me that Obama never wanted to call out Republicans as bad guys, he thought he really could get folks to come together, or thought that calling them out would make him look bad/bring him down to their level.  He did not accomplish that, and now he has to resort to calling them out.  I'm not saying whether this strategy was good or bad, I'm just saying that's how it seems to have played out.

>>> END COMMENT <<<

# News comment title:
Anderson Cooper's Debate Gaffe

# Oldest comment (from the thread):
Cooper's pretty face gives him a lot of power, which he uses to blur the lines between real news and celebrity gossip.  Of course, his legion of female and gay fans won't care if he flubs a statistic because that isn't why they watch him. The good news is that they probably turned off their TV sets once they saw Newt Gingrich.

# Most liked comment (from the thread):
Either that, or income is distribution is hugely unequal.

>>> COMMENT UNDER ANALYSIS<<<


Lots of liberals here* in this internet comment section is equivalent to Anderson Cooper on a nationally televised debate with the candidates for President of the Unites States.  Got it.  

*I'm guessing "lots of liberals here" means one commenter one time in a thread having something to do with corporate taxes rather than a discussion of a misleading and factually incorrect statement about what taxes individuals pay.  I agree, that commenter was wrong to say ExxonMobil pays no taxes, thanks for pointing that out, now both sides are equal.

>>> END COMMENT <<<

# News comment title:
The Debasement of Science

# Oldest comment (from the thread):
Before they react as planned...

"We've seen just a skyrocketing autism rate. Some people are 
suspicious that it's connected to the vaccines. This person included. 
The science right now is inconclusive, but we have to research it."
--Barack Obama, Pennsylvania Rally, April 21, 2008. 

# Most liked comment (from the thread):
Or...a new human life only begins when God decides not to savagely murder the little baby in utero, which we call miscarriage to protect God's image. God hates about 25% to 50% of all these little babies, which is why He murders them.

>>> COMMENT UNDER ANALYSIS<<<


I hesitate to wade in these waters, but I will agree and say, yes a new, distinct, human life is created at conception.  So following up on that debate The Corner was having last week, why is it not considered tragic that so many new human lives are ending prematurely in utero?  Why are the pro-lifers not arguing for it to be illegal to have more than 2 cups of coffee while a woman is pregnant, since that contributes to more deaths of new human lives?  My argument is that it is because the new human life is considered by most (if not the vast majority of people) to be not yet quite a person.

I can understand that there is a distinction between actively ending a new human life and ending one due to negligence.  But on a societal level, it's clear that people overwhelming think that a blastocyst or even an early-stage embryo is not on an equal level as a more developed new distinct human.  Nearly all of us either subconsciously or consciously make that distinction.  The question is when that line is crossed and it is not at conception, and this question is not a scientific one.  I would invite you to argue otherwise because I'm curious if I'm missing something, but to argue that it is a simple scientific "yes or no" question is simply wrong.

>>> END COMMENT <<<

# News comment title:
Some Tax Cuts Are More Equal Than Others

# Oldest comment (from the thread):
The Republicans are like a giant two year old, with the power to destroy the country. They have to be cajoled, and enticed, and tricked, and given time outs in order to get them to eat their oatmeal. One decent thing after another has to be opposed and shrieked over and thrown into the corner, until they stop blubbering and agree.  They are exhausting in their cynically motivated obstructionism . At least we get the payroll tax extension and this time for employers too.

# Most liked comment (from the thread):
Wait, I thought tax cuts paid for themselves.

>>> COMMENT UNDER ANALYSIS<<<


Frankly, I think Republicans' motivations are pretty simple in this case.  

(1) It's a Democratic proposal.  Even though they probably know they have no chance of stopping the payroll tax cut extension, they feel obligated to provide some kind of opposition, as the opposition party.  They're worried it's some kind of trap, so they can't just latch onto it as soon as it is proposed. 

 (2) It's specifically an *Obama* proposal, so their prime directive is challenged.  It's a reflex to be against anything Obama proposes, so they have to actively flex weak brain muscles to come around to their actual preferred position.

I think it's true that Republicans are way more eager to pass tax cuts for the rich, but they aren't *against* tax cuts for middle/lower class folks.  Rather, they are just lackadaisical about them, so all these other motivations dominate.

>>> END COMMENT <<<

# News comment title:
Charts of the Day: Kaiser's Fascinating Obamacare Data

# Oldest comment (from the thread):
Sigh. Obamacare has caused the cost of health insurance to go up. It's not complicated, it's actually fairly simple.

If you require insurance companies to cover more (for example, requiring "children" up to age 26 to be covered under their parents plan), that additional coverage costs more. So, the cost of health insurance goes up.

It'll only get worse. Guaranteed Issue will drive costs way up.

# Most liked comment (from the thread):
Ok, it caused them to go up.  That statement is true if it caused premiums to go up $0.01 per year or $1M.  So *how much* did it make them go up?  Because with or without Obamacare, premiums were going up every single year, and at a rate well above inflation.  

And those increases that were happening anyway, were happening with no increase in coverage to the consumer.  But with ACA, they are going up, but that increase comes with benefits to the consumer.  

If you pay more and get the same, I see a problem (status quo).  If you pay more and get more, I don't see the problem (ACA).  


>>> COMMENT UNDER ANALYSIS<<<


Ok now we're talking about 1-2% increase, of which the coverage for up to 26-year-olds is only a part of that.  It gets smaller with each data point, apparently.  And we're getting value from that other part of the increase.  I think it is worthwhile to pay more for preventative medicine like mammograms, if they are preventing future illnesses.  What is the argument against that?  It is saving us money down the road.  

The other chunk (6-7%) of the increase is caused by...what exactly?  Not ACA. That's the important part.  We could repeal ACA and still be facing the same essential problem, but presumably you'd just throw up your hands and say, "What a rascal, that free market!" I suppose.

>>> END COMMENT <<<

# News comment title:
Charts of the Day: Kaiser's Fascinating Obamacare Data

# Oldest comment (from the thread):
Sigh. Obamacare has caused the cost of health insurance to go up. It's not complicated, it's actually fairly simple.

If you require insurance companies to cover more (for example, requiring "children" up to age 26 to be covered under their parents plan), that additional coverage costs more. So, the cost of health insurance goes up.

It'll only get worse. Guaranteed Issue will drive costs way up.

# Most liked comment (from the thread):
Ok, it caused them to go up.  That statement is true if it caused premiums to go up $0.01 per year or $1M.  So *how much* did it make them go up?  Because with or without Obamacare, premiums were going up every single year, and at a rate well above inflation.  

And those increases that were happening anyway, were happening with no increase in coverage to the consumer.  But with ACA, they are going up, but that increase comes with benefits to the consumer.  

If you pay more and get the same, I see a problem (status quo).  If you pay more and get more, I don't see the problem (ACA).  


>>> COMMENT UNDER ANALYSIS<<<


Simply put, the goal of ACA was to provide universal healthcare. Everything else in the bill is just details either to make it palatable for congress or to fill in the logistical requirements. With (near) universal healthcare established, the next step is refining it, make it work better. I personally think ending the tie with employers will do that. Would it have passed if someone proposed that instead of ACA? No, and I know because that plan was proposed, it was called wyden-Bennett and it went nowhere. I'm not saying it will happen soon now that ACA is in place but rather it will not happen for a very long time if ACA is repealed. 

>>> END COMMENT <<<

# News comment title:
Turning Medicare Into Obamacare

# Oldest comment (from the thread):
Any plan that fails to deal with prescription drug costs is guaranteed to fail, that's the single biggest expense for most seniors.  When any of our political warriors step up to the plate and allow Medicare to negotiate drug costs, then I'll believe they are serious. 

The VA manages to successfully negotiate, there is no early reason why Medicare can't. 

# Most liked comment (from the thread):
The problem with expecting private health insurance companies to be innovative in cutting costs is that the best way to cut costs is to be innovative in new ways to deny care, or to get people to pay for care out of pocket. Those kind of innovations save the insurance company money, but they aren't really cutting the cost of our nation's health care, they are just shifting the cost around.

Frankly, that's my problem with all of capitalism. The Adam Smith idea that competition and the incentive of profits will force businesses to be more efficient doesn't take into account that businesses can also improve their bottom line by figuring out ways to get others to pay their costs, and ways to cut their own labor costs (by cutting salaries), and ways to legally avoid fulfilling their side of contracts.

>>> COMMENT UNDER ANALYSIS<<<


Hey Steve, I'm not "advocating" for anything, especially not what you are suggesting I'm advocating for.  I'm stating that under every single projection of government expenditure and revenue Medicare costs go up to unsustainable levels.  Do you disagree with that statement of fact? If not, then we should both agree that we have to do something about that.  I'm not advocating for this plan.  I'm not advocating for any plan.  I'm saying something must be done.  

I agree with you that if we reduce Medicare expenditures, we are reducing care for the elderly.  I'm not sure why you think I'm disagreeing with you.  It almost seems like you have decided I'm a conservative so talking to me as if  I was one.  I'm not.

# News comment title:
Americans May Not Like Capitalism As Much As Conservatives Think

# Oldest comment (from the thread):
"It is very definitely not accompanied by images of well-coiffed
 guys in suits and green eyeshades, making millions by sitting in 
boardrooms and approving mass layoffs by adding a quick line to a 
spreadsheet before they head out to lunch. But guess what? That's what 
you get with Romney whether you like it or not."

This is, of course, an absurd strawman.  What Bain and similar companies do is help companies deliver a superior product, in part by streamlining the labor force.  It isn't simply a matter of "approving mass layoffs"-- it's doing a deep analysis of the company, it's strong points, it's weak points, competitors, etc.  It's true there's a tragic byproduct of a temporary displacement of some workers who were no longer part of the value stream, but what's the alternative?  Keep entire zombie departments alive long after they've ceased to be relevant/profitable?  This is the sort of analysis the federal government badly needs.

Combining the two saws, if Romney is explaining what he did at Bain, he's not reminding voters that they are mad at the incumbent.  For Romney, his ideal situation is to have the aura of "successful businessman" embedded in the minds of voters, without having to talk about it in any great detail.

# Most liked comment (from the thread):
I assume you know this but here goes anyway:

a) Not all tax cuts are equally stimulative. Generally, the poorer the beneficiaries of the cuts, the more stimulative they are.
b) Obama realized that the only sort of stimulus he could hope to have passed, given Republican intransigence, would be a tax cut.
c) So he sought the most stimulative tax cut available given these parameters.

Some tax cuts -- those beloved of Republicans -- are worthless as stimulus, as decades of experience have demonstrated. Some tax cuts -- those Republicans could care less about -- are stimulative, albeit less so than other options which Republicans vehemently oppose.

>>> COMMENT UNDER ANALYSIS<<<


But you started the discussion by questioning the need for federal tax increases as part of federal deficit reduction.  Then all of a sudden we're talking about how local and state governments spend a lot of money too.  

This conversation slide is why liberals don't believe conservatives when they say they want to reduce the deficit or national debt.  It turns out all conservatives care about is reducing the size of government, whether it is federal, state, or local.  That is the goal, it would seem, and reducing the debt is just a side benefit.  But state and local governments have little to nothing to do with the national debt.  It's impossible to move forward on a specific issue when it turns out the other side is not even really interested in that issue.

So I would ask, is the national debt a problem?  If it is, then let's solve it.  The most realistic way to solve it, is a combination of spending cuts and tax increases. If conservatives only think the debt is a symptom of having too much government, we're going to get no where, because most of the country disagrees with them, and will in perpetuity unless conservatives somehow convince more people that we should reduce SS and Medicare benefits.  Notice conservatives do not get very far when they start advocating that.

# News comment title:
More Specialists Are in Your Medical Future

# Oldest comment (from the thread):
Computers are becoming increasingly more complex.  I guess that explains why the prices keep on going up.

# Most liked comment (from the thread):
Computers are becoming increasingly more complex.  I guess that explains why the prices keep on going up.

>>> COMMENT UNDER ANALYSIS<<<


I'm curious to know why you think Kaiser is "special"?  I assume you mean "can't be readily replicated," but correct me if that is wrong.

It's the largest HMO in the country, and it's growing.  It's constantly building new facilities (at least in my area), yet it has the cheapest insurance premiums (again, in my area).  

I would speculate that if health care was de-coupled from employment, and as a result patients were better able to select their health insurance, Kaiser would grow even more in popularity, but I'm speculating, based on my (positive) experience, and the fact that premiums are generally lower without sacrificing quality of care.  Kaiser isn't just a middle-man trying to make a buck off the patient, like most insurance companies, but they still operate in a relatively competitive market so can't sacrifice quality of care to maintain lower cost.  

Why can't it be replicated?  Because the barriers to entry are so high?  I could see that, but it doesn't mean Kaiser can't keep expanding across the country.



>>> END COMMENT <<<

# News comment title:
The Republican Plan to Let Your Boss Control Your Life

# Oldest comment (from the thread):
The weird part is that the one thing the Republicans won't allow employers to do is make their employees do their job.  They want the employees to be able to refuse to do their job if they have moral objections.

# Most liked comment (from the thread):
One of my problems with modern conservatives is that they embrace reductio ad absurdum arguments before we get a chance to make fun of them.

>>> COMMENT UNDER ANALYSIS<<<


This is just priceless.  You can switch your employer "at will"?  You can sure quit your current job "at will".  You can sure look and apply for a job "at will".  But it seems to me these days the whole "getting a new job" thing isn't quite so easy as it used to be.

Here's the problem I see for conservatives:  You don't even try to convince other people to come on your side.  If you got more people to agree with you, you win elections and your policy can be implemented.  This is a representative democracy, not a debate point scoring contest.  

In this case, people care more about their day to day lives (i.e., their job) than they do about some wispy concept like "freedom".  If a boss is imposing things on them, it's more important to them than if the government is enacting laws that in theory impose on their conceptual freedom.  Why not try to explain why these new birth control-related rules affect their lives instead of telling them, "You don't like it?  Switch yer job, whiner!"
 

>>> END COMMENT <<<

# News comment title:
Who Should We Blame for High Gas Prices?

# Oldest comment (from the thread):
   Some are sort of redundant. If you believe in supply and demand, then blaming gas guzzlers for contributing unneccesarily to demand is a reasonable logical deduction. 

  Blaming governmnet, what does that mean?
(a) Government got in the way of drill-drill-drill.
(b) Gov is manipulating things to raise the price.
(c) Gov has not pushed conservation aggresively enough.

   Then of course the real world is more complicated than single causes, i.e. multiple causes are in play, but I can only pick one?

# Most liked comment (from the thread):
 You don't think energy is a national security issue? No wonder you're a Randian fantasist.



>>> COMMENT UNDER ANALYSIS<<<


True, and that's why I said "up to a point".  But I would argue that the drop in demand in 2008 was a short term drop caused by general panic, manifesting itself as businesses and people pulling back from purchases (including gas).  That response has probably led to a move toward greater mileage efficiency, but that has yet to be fully confirmed (although it's likely).  Even if that's the case, we have a very short term jump in prices now, which suggests inelastic demand.

I'm not sure if just because median incomes are low in China that demand would be more elastic.  China's economy is still growing at a fast pace, and I would speculate that most oil consumed in china goes to businesses (trucking, shipping, etc.), not consumers.

# News comment title:
Mitt Romney's Head Fake to the Center

# Oldest comment (from the thread):
Should be obvious. We're talking about a guy who spray-tanned himself to appear before Latinos.

# Most liked comment (from the thread):
Romney, in this sense, borrowed from George W Bush in adopting the cultural codes of the right without fully embracing their policy craziness. It's why he didn't pay a price for Medicare Plan D, immigration reform friendliness, No Child Left Behind, AIDS compassion, etc. The difference is that Bush had a pitch-perfect tone for the codes: mindless machismo coupled with Christianist piety. His good 'ol boy shtick went straight to the right-wing id. Romney, by contrast, looks pretty much like a plutocrat both in style and substance. Still, Romney can't overcome the associations with the radical birdbrains of the new GOP. If we pay a toll for Jeremiah Wright, San Francisco, and unwed mothers on food stamps, Republicans pay an even higher one for Pat Robertson, Hank Williams, Jr, and Joe Arpaio. Republicans wounds are, if anything, contain a sepsis that is all the more offensive for their bullying nature. Women, Latinos, blacks, gays, and even Jews feel like "others" in their value system. This Romney cannot undo even if he doesn't embody it personally.


>>> COMMENT UNDER ANALYSIS<<<


 "And actions are what really count."  

Yeah, actions like passing universal health care that utilizes private insurance and an individual mandate.  I agree, that's a good action.  

Bipartisan in Massachusetts, socialism in DC!

>>> END COMMENT <<<

# News comment title:
We Should Probably All Calm Down a Bit

# Oldest comment (from the thread):
One side is batshit insane.  If history is any guide, the other side will give in to the crazies of the GOP sooner or later.

Given this reality, your post somehow does not sound right.

# Most liked comment (from the thread):
"No matter how much you hate to hear it, long-term deficit reduction and
 entitlement reform really are pretty important. Just because 
conservatives abuse the point doesn't mean there isn't something to it. "

This is true only if you don't understand that the deficit isn't actually a "debt" that needs to be "paid back" but is simply an addition to the money supply that can remain in circulation indefinitely so long as inflation is under control.  Since there's basically zero inflation these days, deficit reduction (not to mention "entitlement reform") is about as far from important as it can get.

Progressives really need to start getting a clue about how our monetary system actually works.  Failure to do so is just handing another weapon to those whose agenda is to screw the little guy.

>>> COMMENT UNDER ANALYSIS<<<


I think you can definitely find support among commentators.  Matt Yglesias regularly points out that direct cash payments are the best way of providing stimulus money.  Karl Smith at Modeled Behavior is actually your best bet for advocating such a method.  

I think the resistance you get from people who might agree with you in principle is that they think it would be impossible to pass such legislation because people/voters/Republicans find the very idea of "just giving away cash" unthinkable.

# News comment title:
Our Bedpan and Canasta Future

# Oldest comment (from the thread):
"Raise your hand if this sounds like a wonderful vision of the future. Anyone?"

Not to be a downer, but 50 years ago if someone were to describes today's typical work environment, would anyone raise their hands then as if it "sounds like a wonderful vision of the future?"  Reality is what it is, and we can improve on it, but it's not like we're going to find some kind of magic solution where the average person is working on meaningful, fulfilling work that doesn't involve dealing with, to pick a few bits of reality out of a hat, repetitive stress injuries and being taken advantage of by management.
 

# Most liked comment (from the thread):
The last time the disintegration of an entire job category  happened on this kind of a grand scale, was the agricultural revolution.  Farm employment in the US went from 40% of the population to less than 3%. In that transition, people had to move to the cities and find work in factories, primarily.  

I find it hard to believe there won't be anything of value to do that people will be willing to pay for, but it is not going to be an easy transition. Maybe we will start to value the arts more..  crafts..  things that machines can't do well..  I think we are not in a position to see the outlines of the future.

Or, alternatively, perhaps employment for people will go the way of employment for draft horses; our labor won't be worth the price of our material support...  but draft horses have no capability for creativity, and couldn't create new job categories for themselves; whereas humans have an endless capability to create.  

Either way things are ready to change..     

>>> COMMENT UNDER ANALYSIS<<<


My point is not that I believe today's work environment sucks, because it sounds like that is what you are responding to, but rather, depending on what words you choose to briefly describe the average work situation in the future for the average worker, it can sound bad, so no one will "raise their hand" to select it as their preferred future.  

Kevin seems to be a bit of a pessimist about the future, from the tone of the quote I cut and pasted.  I realize it is a bit tongue-in-cheek, but I don't agree with that pessimistic take, I'm more indifferent.  Things will change, but they are what they are.  Work will suck* for most people no matter what we do now to try and change that.

But in any case, the list you describe are a few positive things.  Which are great and all, but reality has pluses and minuses, not all pluses.

*What I mean by "suck" is there will always be something the average person would rather be doing, and to imply that we have any shot at creating a future where that doesn't happen is naive, and not something to strive for.

>>> END COMMENT <<<

# News comment title:
Raw Data: 401(k) Account Balances for Workers Near Retirement

# Oldest comment (from the thread):
I think "back in the day" a worker with a defined-benefit plan would be getting a LOT more retirement income. If the median is half the mean, that means that half of all workers with 401k plans who are nearing retirement had $80K or less in their accounts. That's not nothing but it's also not exactly a retirement plan.

I suppose that if you took that money at 65 and bought a life annuity you might get $6K a  year. Again, not nothing but it's a pathetically small amount of money compared to the kinds of pensions workers used to receive (and some lucky ones still get).

To me that's the real takeaway from this chart.

# Most liked comment (from the thread):
In 1900 a white male who lived until age 70 had an average life expectancy of an additional 9 years. In 2004, a white male who lived until age 70 had an average life expectancy of an additional 13.7 years. This argument that "people live longer today in retirement" is completely overblown, and has nothing to do with why you and your ilk want to shred the welfare state.

http://www.infoplease.com/ipa/A0005140.html

>>> COMMENT UNDER ANALYSIS<<<


I didn't intend to get into a semantic argument.  By "forced" I meant, "if you want to save for retirement and do not have a defined benefit pension, you have to go the 401k route, you have no choice."  I.e., forced.

401k is subject to market fluctuations.  You aren't likely to lose all of it, but you certainly can end up with less than you put in.  Meanwhile, a defined benefit pension is something you put nothing in to.  It's free money.  That's a good deal no matter how you slice it.  

I'm not saying we should pass a law to have defined benefit pensions.  I agree, that would be untenable.  I'm saying if you have access to one, you are getting a good deal.  

>>> END COMMENT <<<

# News comment title:
Here's Why I Don't Think Republicans Will Reach a Sequester Deal With Obama

# Oldest comment (from the thread):
The only thing that really motivates a Republican member of the house is the fear of being primaried by a tea bagger who is more looney than they are.

# Most liked comment (from the thread):
Actually, Democrats would be fine without tax increases IF you hostage takers weren't deploying reflexive nihilism to damage America. But as we all know, you hate this country to the point that you're willing to damage its credit-worthiness. When putatively sane people hate a president (say, Obama) to the point that they're willing to inflict huge damage on the nation itself, a line has been crossed. The Republican Party as a whole has crossed that line. We can differ about the ways to handle the long-term debt issue, but that's not your real concern. Your  concern is only about hurting this nation for short-term political gain. Your principles otherwise are one part burlesque and a bigger part cynicism .

>>> COMMENT UNDER ANALYSIS<<<


What the Democrats "want" is not higher taxes.  Higher taxes are a (partial) *solution* to a problem: the deficit.  A problem you profess to care about.

Democrats don't think cutting spending alone will solve the problem of the deficit without causing other problems.  

Republicans on the other want truly do *want* lower spending.  That's the goal.  They don't "want" to cut the deficit.  The deficit is just a problem they are using as an excuse to get what they really want: lower government spending so they can have lower taxes (mainly for the rich).

# News comment title:
Glenn Kessler Makes a Reasonable Point About What's Serious and What's Not

# Oldest comment (from the thread):
So what do we have on the other side - Ryan's plan? That is neither an actual plan to reduce deficits, since he never specifies actual cuts to be made or any actual increased revenues, nor is it realistic politically. In the real world, the Republican leadership is not going to eliminate Social Security or Medicare, or even take responsibility for cutting them in a detectable way. Ryan is basically a front man to appease the minority of extremists who really want to cut government. Those people will probably never control the party, since actually cutting government services is a political loser.

Has Kessler assessed the reality of Ryan's plan in either mathematical or political terms? If he thinks it is "realistic" he is just showing himself to be a member of the delusional "centrist" faction, which itself is divorced from reality in both senses.

I agree this is a reasonable take, but it's also reasonable to say that when Republicans say Obama "has no plan" that is false, full stop.

And at the same time, everyone should recognize Obama's plan for what it is: a starting point in negotiations.  Any emphasis he puts on any particular item in the plan at this point in the process is just a way to gain leverage.  It's like the sacrificial lamb idea discussed yesterday with TSA knives. Negotiations have to progress before the real priorities show themselves.

To criticize Obama now, is to criticize the speed of negotiations*, without recognizing that the Republicans' critique is unfounded ("Obama has no plan!").

* And mind you the speed of this process is pretty much exactly on schedule.

# News comment title:
The Fight For Our Precious Bodily Fluids

# Oldest comment (from the thread):
Higher access to toothpaste and fluoride rinse in the NE and Pacific coast?  More dentists with political influence? I'm in NJ, and I've always just assumed there was fluoride in the water.  I guess maybe that's not true. 

# Most liked comment (from the thread):
You don't have to consume fluoride. Nobody is in fact, "forcing" fluoride on you. Talk about melodrama. It's your *choice* to take advantage of city water systems or not. You could always go off the grid, or filter it. It's not like the government is pumping fluoride into the water table.

It sounds like you'd just like to bitch because you're provided with probably the easiest source of potable running water you can get, but you don't like that they don't tailor it to meet your specific pet concerns. You sound like a prima donna to me. Why do you want special rights?

Or in true wingnut form: "Ain't no running water guarantee in the Constitution!"

>>> COMMENT UNDER ANALYSIS<<<


I think the slippery slope is just a poor analogy for this type of situation.  Slippery slope suggests that once you start slipping, you can't stop and in fact the slipping will accelerate.   If that were the case, we'd have added all kinds of healthful things by now.  Why not vitamins?  Etc.  The worriers have economics on their side.  Adding things to water for everyone costs lots of money.  The vast majority of water purveyors have every reason to not add more stuff and even to stop fluoridating if it were just based on every day operating costs.  But the argument that overall you're saving money that would have been spent treating tooth decay across the population seems to have won out.

I think it's more like climbing a staircase.  If you take one step, you could go back down that step without much thought.  But once you've taken 10 or 15 steps, you look back down and think, "Well, I've gone this far and it's not so bad, why not a few more steps?"  It's not like we, as a society, are not considering each step.  We *are* subject to status quo bias, but things aren't being added to our water left and right.  Fluoride is the *only* (intentional) additive of it's kind* that I've heard of, and I work in the water industry.

*I would class fluoride as something added specifically to affect the drinker by improving teeth health.  Chlorine is added to disinfect or to keep pipes clean, added remove contaminants and by the time it gets to the user, it is mostly gone from the water.

>>> END COMMENT <<<

# News comment title:
The Most Absurd Religious War in Geek History is in the News Today

# Oldest comment (from the thread):
As far as I know, abbreviations and acronyms don't have strict 'rules' for their pronunciation... 
.MP3 - we read out each character. 
.JPEG - we pronounce one letter, then turn the other three into a word. 
.GIF - rather than read each letter, we attempt to turn this into a word. 'GIFF' appears less often in normal speech than 'JIFF', I guess? And does the pronunciation of the letter in the word being abbreviated (Graphical, in this case) actually matter? In some cases, yes, in others... no.

But a good geek argument is too fun to ignore.   /popcorn. 

# Most liked comment (from the thread):
As far as I know, abbreviations and acronyms don't have strict 'rules' for their pronunciation... 
.MP3 - we read out each character. 
.JPEG - we pronounce one letter, then turn the other three into a word. 
.GIF - rather than read each letter, we attempt to turn this into a word. 'GIFF' appears less often in normal speech than 'JIFF', I guess? And does the pronunciation of the letter in the word being abbreviated (Graphical, in this case) actually matter? In some cases, yes, in others... no.

But a good geek argument is too fun to ignore.   /popcorn. 

>>> COMMENT UNDER ANALYSIS<<<


I know you asked a specific question, and I am not part of the group you were targeting so I apologize.  But I just want to point out one thing:  

gif is one letter away from an actual word: gift.  Gift is pronounced with a hard g.  I know English has weird pronunciations with lots of contradictory exceptions, but to me, it just seems obvious that the gif/gift connection is why it is predominantly pronounced with a hard g.

But that's just my 2 cents.

Incidentally, given how language and pronunciation works, I don't see how the creator of a word is the ultimate authority on how to pronounce it.  The British pronounce lieutenant as "LEF-ten-ant" for crying out loud.  But I digress...

# News comment title:
Republicans Are Missing the Point on Immigration Reform

# Oldest comment (from the thread):
The reason that "taking immigration off the table" probably won't work for the GOP is that passing a bill will enrage their tea party base. By contrast, keeping the issue going is great for House Republicans in safe seats; it prevents a primary challenge and helps energize their base voters. It's not so great for Senate Republicans, but they're not the ones whose hands it is in. 

It's also bad for the 2016 Republican presidential nominee, but I think it's starting to sink in that George W Bush will end up being the last Republican president, at least in our lifetimes if not ever. In 2016 they'll be running a true believer (not a squish like Romney or McCain) who'll go down in a glorious ideologically pure defeat. Then by 2020 Texas will be blue, and that'll be that for Republican presidents.

I think they're right that opposing immigration reform is the right move for them. That's because there aren't any moves that lead away from oblivion for the Republican party.

# Most liked comment (from the thread):
The reason that "taking immigration off the table" probably won't work for the GOP is that passing a bill will enrage their tea party base. By contrast, keeping the issue going is great for House Republicans in safe seats; it prevents a primary challenge and helps energize their base voters. It's not so great for Senate Republicans, but they're not the ones whose hands it is in. 

It's also bad for the 2016 Republican presidential nominee, but I think it's starting to sink in that George W Bush will end up being the last Republican president, at least in our lifetimes if not ever. In 2016 they'll be running a true believer (not a squish like Romney or McCain) who'll go down in a glorious ideologically pure defeat. Then by 2020 Texas will be blue, and that'll be that for Republican presidents.

I think they're right that opposing immigration reform is the right move for them. That's because there aren't any moves that lead away from oblivion for the Republican party.

>>> COMMENT UNDER ANALYSIS<<<


I think the lesson you've pointed out is: if you want to win some elections, you aren't going to win on every policy issue.  

Arguably, "Democrats trying to take gun control off the table by kowtowing to the NRA." helped the Dems in 2006 and 2008.  I think the War on Terror issue was more a fact of Dems realizing they were fighting a losing battle and stiff opposition would only make it worse, while gaining no ground on policy (again, arguable).

The question is: given a specific issue, is it worth it to "get it off the table" while accepting the fact that you've lost ground on that policy issue?  I don't think it's always a cut and dry answer, need to evaluate each circumstance, and even then you're subject to events outside your control.

Before some 1980 and 1981 opinions issued by then-Attorney General Benjamin Civiletti, a failure to fund some part of the government didn't necessarily mean that that part of government would stop functioning. # News comment title:
How Proton Beams Are a Metaphor for our Broken Health Care System

# Oldest comment (from the thread):
But but but, proton beams are COOL!! For one thing, proton sounds really close to "photon" and anyone who has ever watched Star Trek knows that photon torpedos are THE BOMB (a pun on at least three different levels).

So here's a personal story about the inexorable growth of the "medical industrial complex." In the late sixties my (late and beloved) father was recruited to Seattle to start up an organ transplant program. The UW hospital in those days was an unassuming little red brick building at the corner of Pacific and Montlake. Dad got what was considered an absolutely average office for an Associate Professor, north side, fifth floor, looking out over a small patch of grass. Over the years the place expanded, expanded, and expanded some more, to the point that by the mid-90s the medical complex took up the entire block (making it well over half a mile long) and including a massively expanded dental school, PT school (one of the best in the nation IMO), biochemistry/biophysics divisions, etc. The original red brick building basically disappeared from view, except for a tiny patch visible on the south (Montlake Cut) side if you knew where to look. The view outside dad's office also changed greatly over the years with all the expansions, and at one point in the late 80s he looked down on an underground atrium which provided light to the particle accelerator that was used to generate radioactive isotopes for cancer treatment, an entire massive facility in and of itself which has since been removed. One particularly delicious irony is that when he passed some years ago the jockeying in the department over who would get his office was intense! His once relatively nondescript office was now prime real estate because it was one of the few remaining with a separate space for a secretary (as if the department would pay for THAT anymore) AND an external window. Progress!

# News comment title:
Chart of the Day: Wall Street Is Starting to Get Nervous About the Debt Ceiling

# Oldest comment (from the thread):
Not to worry, according to shooter242 and all the other pro-default folks, we take in way more money than we owe in bond debt service, so we're good.  Nevermind what these so-called "investors" are doing.

# Most liked comment (from the thread):
Yeah yeah yeah... and Lehmann Brothers was a relatively small investment bank, so letting them go under wouldn't cause more than a ripple in the markets. No way it could lead to a Global Thermonuclear Financial Meltdown™, right?

As lots of smart people have pointed out for decades, financial markets are highly unstable, frequently chaotic systems, particularly in times of high uncertainty. In 2008 Lehmann was a drop in the larger world financial market, but their failure created massive uncertainty via a sequence of "what ifs?" that caused short term lending to dry up world-wide. Suddenly the commercial paper window was closed, meaning countless mid- and large-sized companies from Alabama to Zanzibar couldn't make payroll or finance their inventory. That created even more "what ifs?" and within a week — when our lovely Congress continued their streak of being wrong each and every FU***** time by voting down the bailout — the markets were in free fall and the US economy was contracting at what was later determined to be a 9% rate, a level of collapse previously considered impossible in a modern economy.

US Treasury Bills are the bedrock of the world financial system. Neither sexy nor high-paying, but the SINGLE SAFEST investment there is. As Paul Krugman again pointed out the other day, so safe that they frequently carry negative real interest rates, meaning they are considered safer than cash. Up to now the markets have been "pricing in" the perception that the GOP wouldn't be crazy enough to jump off this particular financial cliff, but thanks to the lunacy surrounding the CR and Obamacare that "discount" is disappearing and yield curves are going to leap. 

Under the best of circumstances world finance is a house of cards held up by trust and optimism. Shake the bottom-most cards — or more literally, the table they're stacked on — and it will all come tumbling down in days. Hard to say how this plays out, but with each passing day it becomes more likely that the government shutdown and the debt ceiling become intertwined, which might be a good thing from a political point of view, but which create enormous uncertainty — i.e., panic — for the markets.

We do indeed live in interesting times...

# News comment title:
Why Are We Talking About the Debt Ceiling Crisis As If It's Normal Politics?

# Oldest comment (from the thread):
A democratic government is premised on an assumption that despite disagreements, citizens and their representatives agree about the overall aims. They can disagree about means to achieve the aim, and they can disagree about particular goods that are perhaps inessential to the overall aim, but they still agree about what the greater good is. The problem here is that there are a real minority who either disagree about the overall aim, or refuse to acknowledge that there is general agreement on the overall aim. It is next to impossible to run anything let alone a country if there is no presumed shared goal through which disagreements can be moderated.

This is an interesting response, and it makes a certain bit of sense.  I don't buy it as somehow more effective than having the voters vote on their Senator, but it sheds some light on the intent, if it's true.  But if you look at the history of what led to direct election of Senators, giving the legislatures this power led to many instances of vacant Senate seats, because they couldn't decided on who to appoint.  So the responsiveness concept may have been the *intent* of that provision, but a non-existent Senator is fundamentally less responsive than a popularly elected Senator.

And to be a tad more serious, the evidence that we're locked into an extended liquidity trap, with low interest rates, poor avenues for investment, and (most importantly) aggregate demand falling short of aggregate supply is everywhere. It shows in the lack of inflation, in the complaints by people like Bill Gross that even risky investments don't offer a decent return, in the comments by economists as diverse as Krugman/Stiglitz and Summers/Cowan that we're entering a "new normal", etc. The best way of raising aggregate demand relative to aggregate supply is to distribute buying power to those who have little or none (either that, or have another event like WWII, which both raised demand AND destroyed a lot of supply, a TWOFER!). Unfortunately, one of the "dirty little secrets" here is that to be really effective it wouldn't be enough to redistribute a little wealth in the US, what's needed is to make the poorer people's of the world, in particular, the median residents of China, India and Africa, a little bit better off. # News comment title:
Movies, Movies Everywhere, But Not a Drop to Watch

# Oldest comment (from the thread):
Amazon prime video has a much, much better selection. I dropped Netflix because it never has anything I want to see.

# Most liked comment (from the thread):
Among my other "occupations" I've followed this space for years, ever since I oversaw implementing video content on the Netscape portal ten years ago(Sigh...  may it rest in peace) so this is a part of the digital media world where I feel pretty confident in my opinions.


First, it's extremely unlikely that DVDs by mail will go away as there is a proven market for that approach. Even in their original attempt to go "streaming only" Netflix tried to start up the parallel Qwikster service (the New Coke of video distribution). So either Netflix will maintain this service or some other company will fill the gap, as there is clearly a significant "I want to watch X and don't mind waiting a few days" audience to be served. It's possible the market will shrink enough that it's no longer sensible for the Netflix to have a distribution center within 1-2 days post of every major city in the US, but DVDs by mail is such a beautiful business model — long tail distribution, high leverage off existing infrastructure, over-subscription producer surplus, low customer management costs, etc. — I don't see it going away any time soon.


Note that DVDs by mail is fundamentally different from the "local video store" model which had extremely high fixed costs (both in terms of infrastructure and labor), zero consumer surplus and heavy rent seeking in the form of late fees (fully a third of Blockbuster's revenue at their height).


Second, the availability of content for streaming will continue to improve, albeit in fits and starts, for the foreseeable future. Having seen the way digital distribution roiled both the music and publishing industries — both deserved it, although for different reasons — Hollywood and the TV production studios have simultaneously been both more forward looking in their strategy, but more cautious in their implementation. The days when The Wizard of Oz would be shown only once a year, or Disney could re-release it's classic animation features on a rolling 5-8 year schedule, are forever gone (may they NOT rest in peace). 


There are still turf wars being waged between the different delivery channels in terms of Hulu vs. Netflix vs. Amazon vs. "proprietary" like the networks' own web sites, which limits options. But eventually a classic aggregation-syndication business model will take hold for all but high end or specialized content (viz., the WSJ or New Yorker in the publishing industry) and most will be available through multiple channels. As the technology and bandwidth improve cable will either disappear or, more likely, evolve into a content buffet with a la carte offerings.

>>> COMMENT UNDER ANALYSIS<<<


Movies?  Or TV shows?  Or both?  I always had the impression Amazon Prime had even more slim pickings, but it could be because I find the interface less easy to browse (i.e., if you know what you are looking for you can find it, but it's not as easy to simply happen upon something you would like to watch).  I have both and feel I don't take advantage of Amazon Prime video enough, so I'd love to hear some tips if you have any!

>>> END COMMENT <<<

>>> COMMENT UNDER ANALYSIS<<<


1. That's your claim.  But the evidence shows when the jobs dry up, so does the flow of immigrants.  More jobs, more immigrants, and less reason to fear immigrants.

2. Read the article instead of just the headlines: "Gross domestic product, the broadest measure of goods and services churned out by the economy, grew at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 3.2% in the fourth quarter, the Commerce Department said. 3. Again, look at the evidence.  Yes, wages are decreased (slightly) in the near term, but not in the long term.

# News comment title:
Who Deserves Credit for Reducing the Federal Deficit?

# Oldest comment (from the thread):
>>Tax and spending policy makes a difference, but not much of one

Sorry Kevin, I gotta call BS on that one, at least in the case of one George W. Bush. His tax cuts represented a massive shift in the overall fiscal health of the US (and hint, it wasn't a shift for the better). Yes, the surpluses of the late 90s weren't as good as they seemed at the time, pumped up by unusually strong growth and a frothy tech driven stock market, but after the Democrats (and yes, GHWB) having the cajones to raise taxes twice, and the wise leadership of the Clinton years with things like Pay-Go, the deficit was well and truly under control for the first time in a couple generations. Bush and his delusional "Ownership Society" policy advisors destroyed that several times over and now we're burdened with structural deficits for the foreseeable future. And while you're right about the accounting identity, we'd be (IMO) a hell of a lot better off running a smaller deficit and having the option of working towards a trade surplus than to be locked into situation we're in now.

# News comment title:
There's No Good Reason for Keeping OLC Opinions Confidential

# Oldest comment (from the thread):
The most compelling arguments on the other side are (1) that the advice of the OLC is similar to attorney-client privilege. (2) That if the OLC knew its opinions were going to be released publicly they would be tempted to mash them down into pabulum for political reasons.

The first argument isn't very convincing, and in just this short post Kevin (and Sargent before him) have pretty much skewered it. The second, given the nature of bureaucracies is almost certainly true, but not a remotely cogent argument for what we have now and, in fact, might be considered yet another reason to open up the process: The OLC, as a part of the government, should not be giving recommendations that don't pass political muster. 

Does a President occasionally need to take actions that the public (in whole or part) does not like or is not ready to accept? Of course! That's one of the prices of leadership. But those decisions shouldn't be given the patina of OLC support, particularly in secret. (Any reminders here of the odious John Yu and his cravenly rationalized torture memos are entirely intentional.)

# News comment title:
Low Inflation Continues to Disappoint Inflation Hawks

# Oldest comment (from the thread):
NBC News. Isn't that an oxymoron?

# Most liked comment (from the thread):
Oh for the love of god, when somebody says "inflation is at 1.6 percent" they aren't saying that volatility in food prices is a-ok.  Inflation is a specific measure of the slippage between the money supply and aggregate demand.  It gives you a sense of what, if any, macroeconomic tools should be brought to bear on the system.  

Issues with energy prices being up or down, or with income disparity, or with the affordability of basic household goods, are not measured by looking at the inflation rate--they have their own separate metrics and indicators.  And they are important.  But complaining that the metric for inflation doesn't also also provide "relei[f]" for "those folks out there struggling with meager budgets" is like complaining that your odometer doesn't tell you enough about your oil pressure.  It's dumb. 

As is the anti-intellectual foolishness about "economic gurus" being best relegated to garbage trucks.  Frankly, it's been said gurus that have been pushing for measures that have ameliorated the recession (stabilization funding, stimulus, expanding the fed's balance sheet), while populist idiots (primarily, although sadly not exclusively on the right) have been pushing a lot of destructive nonsense about belt-tightening and austerity, all in the name of some phantom inflation that hasn't troubled us for close to 30 years.

>>> COMMENT UNDER ANALYSIS<<<

# News comment title:
Rick Perry Indictment Highlights the Hack Gap Once Again

# Oldest comment (from the thread):
Really, Kevin -- you think that the fact Brown supposedly (in edited footage) shoplifted should have any bearing on the fact he was shot six times? 

Wow. Talk about a hack.

# Most liked comment (from the thread):
To put it in perspective, consider Rod Blagojevich.  Among the many well-supported charges of corruption, there was the matter of filling the senate seat that had then recently been vacated by President Obama.


A Blagojevich defender might argue that the governor has the sole power to make that appointment, and that it's entirely proper for him to consider his political benefit when doing so. He could appoint a friend. He could appoint himself. He could trade the appointment for support for one of his legislative priorities.

But there's a clear line between using the powers of his office for his political benefit and using them for his personal financial benefit, or for that of his family. He committed a crime when he tried to trade the senate seat for campaign cash, or for a sinecure for him and/or his wife.


So, to Perry. He can use his line item veto to advance his political agenda. He can use it to punish enemies and reward allies.  If he wants to use his line-item veto to wipe out departments under Democratic control, he can do that, and he's accountable only to the voters of his state.


Where he may have crossed the line, though, is in shutting down a unit that was looking into corruption among some of his friends/family. That's obstruction of justice, and the fact that he's using his official powers, and doing it out in the open, can't sanctify a fundamentally corrupt motive.

>>> COMMENT UNDER ANALYSIS<<<

I'm so surprised there is more to the story than the selectively edited video released by the obviously corrupt police department!

    - If the stance is in favor of the target or agrees with the target, write FAVOR
    - If the stance is against the target or disagrees with the target, write AGAINST
    - If the stance is ambiguous, write NONE
    - If the comment is not related to the target, write NOT RELATED

    ### KEY CLAIM ###
    - Extract the fundamental assertion or belief that form the basis of the commenter's stance
    - The key claim should be expressed impersonalizing the user in the form of "I agree with the following: <extracted claim>".
    - If no stance is expressed (NOT RELATED, NONE) then leave the explanation field empty. 

    ### Output Format: ###

    You must output only JSON format:
    {
      "results": [
        {
          "target": "<original_target>", 
          "stance": "<one among [FAVOR, AGAINST, NONE, NOT RELATED]>", 
          "stance_type": "<one among [EXPLICIT, IMPLICIT, NONE]>",
          "explanation": "<I agree with the following: ...> if stance in FAVOR/AGAINST"
        },
        // Repeat for each target
      ]
    }
    
    ONLY return the JSON object itself.
